Honestly, a lot of it was just… surviving. Day to day. Trying to get through school, trying to deal with my feelings, trying to figure out what the heck I was going to do with my life.

Bren was huge. Seriously. She was my rock. She didn't judge me, she just listened. She helped me research adoption, she went to appointments with me, she just… *was there*. I don't know what I would have done without her.

My dad too, even though he was quiet about it. He just… showed up. Made sure I was eating, made sure I was okay. He wasn't always good with words, but his actions spoke volumes.

I also leaned on my poetry. Writing helped me process my emotions, to make sense of everything that was happening. It was a way to express myself when I didn't have the words to say out loud.

And I tried to maintain some semblance of normalcy. I still hung out with my friends (when Leah would hang out with me, anyway), I still listened to music, I still went to movies. I needed those things to remind me that I was still me, even with everything going on.

But it was also about accepting that things were different now. That I couldn't just go back to the way things were before. I had to grow up faster, to take on more responsibility.

It was scary, and it was painful, and it was confusing. But it also made me stronger. It taught me a lot about myself, about my values, about what's really important in life.

I still have moments where I feel lost and overwhelmed. But I'm learning to cope. I'm learning to ask for help. And I'm learning to trust myself.

It wasn't the way I imagined my junior year would go, that's for sure. But it was… an experience. And it's one that I'll never forget. It shaped me, it changed me, and it made me who I am today. And honestly? I think I'm okay with that. Even if it's still a little messy.

Okay, so Mark. He's… different than I expected. In a good way. I kinda pictured him being all serious and dad-like, you know? Like, grilling me about my future plans and making sure I understood the gravity of the situation.

He was definitely concerned about those things, but he wasn't… intimidating. He was just… *nice*. Really nice.

He tried really hard to make me comfortable. He asked me about my interests, about my music, about my friends. He actually listened when I talked, which is more than I can say for some people.

We went to a record store together, which was kinda cool. He didn't know much about indie music, but he was genuinely interested in learning. He even bought me a record, a Belle & Sebastian album. It was a really thoughtful gesture.

He and Vanessa both kept asking me what *I* wanted. Not just about the adoption, but about my life. They wanted to know what made me happy, what my dreams were. It was… weirdly refreshing.

He's a little bit awkward sometimes, which I appreciate. He's not trying to be cool or impress me. He's just being himself. And he's a really good listener. He just… *gets* it, you know?

It's still weird, thinking about them raising my baby. It's a lot to process. But spending time with Mark, and with Vanessa, has made me feel a lot better about it. They seem like really good people. They seem like they'll be amazing parents.

He's not trying to replace me, or pretend like I don't exist. He's just… welcoming me into their lives. And that means a lot. It really does. It's still scary, but… less scary than it was before. He's a good guy, Mark. A really good guy.

(Rolls eyes so hard I think I pulled something) Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That kid.

Okay, so, it was… awkward. Beyond awkward. Mortifying is probably a better word.

We were at the arcade, right? Trying to have a normal-ish date, which is hard enough as it is when you're secretly pregnant. And he just… blurted it out.

"Whoa. You're… getting bigger."

Like, thanks, Bleeker. Really observant. I hadn't noticed. It's not like I'm trying to hide it or anything. Oh wait, yes I am.

I just stared at him. I didn't know what to say. I wanted to be angry, but I was also just… embarrassed.

He immediately realized he'd said something wrong, and he started stammering and apologizing. It was even more awkward.

I just told him it was okay, and tried to change the subject. But the whole thing just ruined the mood.

It was a reminder that everyone was noticing. That I couldn't hide this forever. And that it was going to be a long few months.

Honestly, it wasn't the comment itself that bothered me. It was the fact that it was so… blunt. And that it was said in public.

Bleeker's a sweet kid, but he's not exactly the most tactful person in the world. He just says whatever's on his mind, without thinking.

I guess I should have been more prepared for people to notice. But I wasn't. And it was a really uncomfortable moment.

So yeah. That was not a fun day. And I definitely needed a large pizza and a good movie to recover. And maybe a new boyfriend. Just kidding. Mostly.

(Takes a deep breath, looks down at my hands) Okay. That's… a hard question. It's not like there's just *one* thing. It's a lot of things, all tangled up together.

But if I had to pick the most challenging part… it's the letting go.

Like, intellectually, I knew it was the right decision. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. I knew I wanted the baby to have a good life, with parents who were prepared and able to provide for them.

But emotionally… it's been brutal.

It's the feeling of… emptiness. Like a part of me is missing. It's the constant wondering about what the baby's life will be like. Will they be happy? Will they be healthy? Will they ever know who I am?

It's the guilt. Even though I know I'm doing the right thing, I still feel guilty. Guilty for not being able to raise the baby myself. Guilty for giving them away.

And it's the fear. The fear of forgetting. The fear of regretting my decision. The fear of never being able to move on.

I've been trying to focus on the positive. On the fact that I'm giving the baby a good life. On the fact that Mark and Vanessa are wonderful people.

But it's still hard. It's the hardest thing I've ever done.

And the letting go… it's not a one-time thing. It's a process. It's something I'm going to have to work through for a long time.

It's like… saying goodbye to a piece of your heart. And knowing that you'll never get it back.

So yeah. The letting go. That's been the most challenging part. And it's something I'm still struggling with. But I'm trying. I'm really trying. And I'm hoping that someday, I'll be able to look back on this and know that I made the right decision. Even if it was the hardest decision of my life.

(Rolls eyes, sighs dramatically) Oh, *that* guy. Seriously. He was… a lot.

He was holding a sign with a picture of a baby and he kept yelling, and I mean *yelling*, about how babies are "tiny humans with rights" and how "every life is precious." He said something about how a baby is a "gift from God" and that abortion is "murder." It was… intense.

He kept trying to make eye contact with people going into the clinic, and he'd shout things like, "Don't throw your baby away!" and "Think of the little hands and feet!" It was really upsetting, honestly.

It just felt… judgmental. Like he didn't understand that people have complicated reasons for making these kinds of decisions. Like he didn't understand that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is *not* bring a child into the world.

He didn't seem to realize that a baby isn't just a tiny human. It's a whole life. And it deserves a good life. And sometimes, a good life isn't possible.

It was just… a really uncomfortable situation. And it made me feel even more conflicted about everything. It's not like I *wanted* to not have this baby, but I knew it was the right thing to do. And that guy just made it feel so much harder.

Ugh. Just thinking about him makes me want to listen to The Moldy Peaches and hide under a blanket. He was… a lot. A *lot* a lot.

(Looks down, fiddles with her hands. Takes a deep breath.)

Okay. This is… not a fun memory. But you asked.

It was Mr. Pearl. He was… older. And he was standing outside the clinic with a sign. A really graphic sign, showing pictures of… well, you can imagine. It was awful.

He was yelling things too. About how I was "murdering a baby" and how I was going to "burn in hell." It was… terrifying. And humiliating.

I tried to ignore him, to just walk past. But he stopped me. He grabbed my arm, not hard, but enough to make me jump.

He looked me right in the eye and said, "You're making a terrible mistake. You'll regret this for the rest of your life."

And then he said something that really stuck with me. He said, "That baby has a right to live."

It wasn't the yelling that got to me. It was the look in his eyes. It was the judgment. It was the way he made me feel like I was a bad person.

I just… pulled away and ran inside. I was crying. I was shaking. I didn't even want to go through with it anymore.

But then I talked to the counselor, and she reminded me why I was doing this. She reminded me that I was making the best decision for everyone involved.

And I realized that Mr. Pearl didn't know my story. He didn't know my circumstances. He didn't know anything about me. He was just projecting his own beliefs onto me.

It was a horrible experience. But it also made me stronger. It made me more determined to do what was right for me, regardless of what anyone else thought.

I still think about him sometimes. And it still makes me angry. But I also feel sorry for him. He's clearly a very unhappy person. And I hope that someday, he'll find peace.

(Looks away, voice quiet)

It just… wasn't a good day. Not at all.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh. *That*. Ugh. Don't even get me started on Su-Chin.

Okay, so, I was just trying to be honest, right? I was telling her about Paulie and how… intense he was. And I mentioned that he was taking Adderall to help him focus. I figured it was just a detail, you know? Part of the story.

But Su-Chin's face just… changed. She went completely pale. And she started asking all these really intense questions about it. Like, "Is he addicted?" and "Is he dangerous?" and "Are you taking it too?"

It was so awkward. And she kept saying things like, "Adderall is a gateway drug!" and "You need to be careful!"

I tried to explain that Paulie wasn't a bad person, and that he was just trying to get through school. But she wouldn't listen. She was totally fixated on the Adderall.

She kept giving me this look, like I was making a terrible mistake. Like I was about to ruin my life.

Honestly, it was really judgmental. And it made me feel really uncomfortable. I just wanted to change the subject.

She eventually calmed down, but she kept bringing it up throughout the session. It was like she couldn't let it go.

It just… reinforced my feeling that adults sometimes overreact to things. Like, it's just a pill. It doesn't define a person. But Su-Chin made it seem like it was the end of the world.

So yeah. Su-Chin did *not* react well to the mention of Adderall. It was a whole thing. And honestly, it was one of the reasons I started to question whether therapy was even helping. It was just… a lot.

(Shivers a little, even thinking about it) Okay, don't make me relive this. It was… bad.

It wasn't the sterile smell, or the uncomfortable chairs, or even the magazines that were all like, five years old. It was the *people*.

Specifically, it was the couples. All these… glowing, excited couples. Holding hands, whispering to each other, looking at baby clothes in catalogs. They looked so… ready. So *happy*.

And I was sitting there, alone, with a secret that felt like it was eating me alive. I was about to find out if I was even further along than I thought, and I was about to have to make a decision that would change my life forever.

And everyone else looked like they were on this perfect path, this fairytale journey to parenthood. And I felt like I was… broken. Like I was ruining everything.

It wasn't that I was judging them, it was just… the contrast. It was like I was looking at a different world. A world I wasn't a part of.

And then there was this one couple, they were just beaming at each other, talking about names. And I just… panicked. I felt like everyone could see right through me. Like they knew my secret.

I started sweating, and my heart was racing, and I just wanted to run. I wanted to disappear.

It was terrifying. It was like being surrounded by happiness while you're drowning in sadness. It was a really awful feeling. And it's a feeling I won't soon forget.

So yeah. The couples. That's what caught my attention and made me feel terrified in the waiting room. It was a stark reminder of everything I was losing, and everything I wasn't ready for. It was… a lot.

(Scoffs, then a slight blush creeps onto her cheeks)

Ugh. Seriously? We're still talking about Bleeker? It's been… a while.

Okay, fine. Yes. I… still think about him sometimes. Don't get me wrong, it's not like I'm pining away or anything. I'm not writing him love letters or anything ridiculous.

But he was… sweet. And funny. And he actually *listened* to me. He didn't judge me. He just… accepted me for who I was. Which was kind of a big deal.

Things were complicated, obviously. He was a little… awkward. And we were both going through a lot. And then… well, then everything happened with the baby. And things just kind of fell apart.

I haven't talked to him in months. I don't even know if he knows about the adoption.

I think… I think I'll always have a soft spot for him. He was my first… everything. And that's something I'll never forget.

But I'm also realistic. We're both moving on with our lives. And I think it's probably best if we just stay friends. Or… acquaintances. Or whatever.

It's just… a complicated situation. And I don't really want to talk about it anymore. Okay? Can we please talk about something else? Like, I don't know, vintage clothes or indie music or anything? Please? This is awkward.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh. My. God. Okay, don't get me wrong, Vanessa is a lovely woman. Truly. She's sweet and kind and she makes amazing cookies. But her decorating choices… are a *choice*.

It's… beige. Everything is beige. Beige walls, beige carpet, beige furniture. It's like walking into a giant oatmeal bowl.

And there are animals *everywhere*. Like, a whole menagerie of stuffed animals. Lions, tigers, bears… oh my. It's a little overwhelming.

She keeps saying she wants it to be "calming" and "neutral." But it just feels… bland. And boring.

I tried to suggest a little bit of color, maybe a bright accent wall or some funky artwork. But she just smiled and said, "Oh, honey, we want it to be a peaceful environment."

Peaceful? It looks like a hospital waiting room.

Mark is trying to mediate, bless his heart. He keeps saying, "It's a good compromise, Juno." But I'm not sure what he's compromising on. Beige is not a compromise. It's a surrender.

I'm not going to say anything else, though. It's their house, their baby. I just hope the baby doesn't develop a lifelong aversion to the color beige.

Honestly, I'm secretly planning to sneak in a few vintage posters and a brightly colored rug when they're not looking. Just to add a little bit of personality. Don't tell Vanessa. It'll be our little secret. It needs a little… *me* in there, you know? A little bit of life. It's a baby's room, not a beige bunker.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh, *nesting*. Right. That's… complicated.

Look, I'm giving this baby up for adoption. It's not like I'm planning on keeping him or her. So the whole idea of decorating a nursery and buying tiny clothes and… it feels weird. Like, I'm pretending this baby is going to be *mine* forever.

And it's painful. It reminds me of everything I'm giving up.

Mark and Vanessa are really excited about it, though. They've been sending me pictures of the nursery they're decorating. It's really cute. All pastel colors and stuffed animals. It's… nice.

They asked if I wanted to help, and I said no. I just couldn't handle it. It would be too emotional.

I did pick out a few books for the baby, though. I wanted him or her to have some good stories to read. And I knitted a little hat. It's not very good, but it's made with love.

But that's as far as I'm going. I'm trying to focus on the fact that this baby is going to have a wonderful life with Mark and Vanessa. And that they're going to take care of him or her.

I'm not a mom. And I don't need a nursery to prove it.

It's a bittersweet feeling, though. I want the baby to have everything he or she needs. But I also need to protect myself. I need to remember that this is the right decision.

So yeah. Nesting. It's not my thing. It's just… too much. It's a reminder of everything I'm losing. And I need to focus on the future, not the past. It's hard, but I'm trying. Really trying.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh, *those* women. Don't even get me started.

It was… surreal. Like stepping into another dimension. They were all perfectly coiffed and dressed in designer clothes, gliding around the mall like they owned the place. And the *shopping*… it was insane.

They weren't buying things they *needed*. They were buying things they *wanted*. Like, a $500 scarf or a pair of shoes that cost more than my entire wardrobe.

And they weren't even enjoying it! They were all stressed and demanding and completely disconnected from reality. It was like they were trying to fill a void with material possessions.

It just felt… empty. And sad.

I mean, I like shopping as much as the next person. But I like finding a good deal, or a unique vintage piece. I don't like spending a fortune on something just because it has a fancy label.

It made me realize how different their world is from mine. They have so much, and they still seem unhappy. And I have so little, and I'm still trying to find joy in the small things.

It was a good reminder to appreciate what I have, and to not get caught up in the consumerist trap. And it made me want to go thrifting even more. Because why spend a fortune when you can find something amazing for a fraction of the price?

Honestly, it was a little bit terrifying. And a little bit depressing. But it was also… fascinating. Like watching a documentary about a different species. A very wealthy, very stressed-out species.

So yeah. Those women. They were… a lot. And I'm glad I'm not one of them. No offense. But seriously. A $500 scarf? Come on.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment) Okay. That's… a big question. And honestly? It's terrifying.

I mean, I knew this was going to be hard. I knew it was going to be a lot of responsibility. But it's different actually *feeling* it. It's different knowing that I'm bringing a life into the world, even if I'm not the one raising it.

It's not about the sleepless nights or the diaper changes or the financial burden. It's about the emotional weight of it all. It's about knowing that this little person is going to need love and support and guidance for the rest of their life.

And I want to give them that. I want to be a good mother, even if it's from a distance. I want to make sure they're happy and healthy and safe.

But I'm also scared. Scared that I'm not good enough. Scared that I'll make the wrong decisions. Scared that I'll mess things up.

I'm trying to focus on the positive. I'm trying to believe that Mark and Vanessa are going to be amazing parents. And I'm trying to trust that I've made the right decision.

It's a weird feeling, letting go. It's like a part of me is going with the baby. But I also know that it's the best thing for everyone involved.

I'm still figuring out what my role will be in the baby's life. I want to be involved, but I also want to respect Mark and Vanessa's boundaries.

It's a lot to process. It's a lot to handle. But I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to be strong. And I'm trying to focus on the future.

It's not the future I imagined for myself. But it's my future. And I'm going to make the best of it. Even if it's scary. Even if it's hard. Because that's what you do, right? You face your fears and you keep moving forward. And you hope for the best.

Okay, you're getting into the really personal stuff now. But alright, I'll answer. It's not like I haven't thought about this a million times.

It's not about finding "perfect" parents, because honestly, who is? It's more about… finding parents who I think will give the baby the life I can't.

Mark and Vanessa… they've been trying to have a baby for years. They *want* a baby. Like, really want one. And they have a stable home, a good life, and a lot of love to give.

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who I am and what I want to do with my life. I'm not ready to be a mom right now. I wouldn't be able to give the baby the kind of life it deserves.

I want the baby to have a family who is prepared and excited and financially secure. I want the baby to have opportunities that I wouldn't be able to provide.

And Mark and Vanessa… they're not looking for a "perfect" baby either. They're open to learning and growing and adapting. They're not expecting me to just hand over the baby and disappear. They want to stay in touch, to let me know how the baby is doing.

It's not about giving up on the baby. It's about making the best decision for the baby. And I truly believe that Mark and Vanessa are the best people to give the baby a good life.

It's not easy. It's heartbreaking, actually. But it's the right thing to do. And I have to keep reminding myself of that. It's not about what *I* want. It's about what's best for the baby. And that's all that matters.

Okay, deep breaths. This is… a lot to think about. Keeping the baby isn't something I've completely ruled out, but it's definitely not the easy path. And there are a *ton* of obstacles.

First, and most obviously, **finances**. I'm sixteen. I don't have a job that makes enough to support a child. My dad and Bren are supportive, but they have their own bills to pay. Raising a baby is expensive – diapers, formula, clothes, healthcare… it all adds up. It's scary to think about.

Second, **education**. I want to finish high school, and maybe even go to college. But how am I supposed to do that with a baby? It would be incredibly difficult to balance school and motherhood. I'd probably have to drop out, or at least take a lot of time off. And that would limit my future opportunities.

Third, **emotional maturity**. I'm still figuring out who I am. I'm still learning how to navigate relationships and responsibilities. I'm not sure I'm ready to be a parent. It's a huge responsibility, and I don't want to mess it up.

Fourth, **social stigma**. Let's be real, being a teenage mom comes with a lot of judgment. I'd have to deal with stares, whispers, and assumptions. It would be isolating and difficult.

Fifth, **my own dreams**. I have goals and aspirations. I want to travel, to write, to explore my creativity. I'm worried that having a baby would derail those dreams.

And finally, **the baby's well-being**. I want to give this baby the best possible life. And I'm not sure I can provide that right now. I want the baby to have stability, security, and opportunities. And I'm not sure I can offer those things on my own.

It's not that I don't love the idea of being a mom. It's just that I'm realistic about the challenges. And I want to make the best decision for both myself and the baby. And right now, that decision seems to be adoption. But it's something I'm still thinking about. It's not easy. It's not black and white. It's just… complicated. Really complicated.

(Sighs, looking down for a moment) Oh man. That's… a hard memory.

Leah, she… she wanted me to just *keep* the baby. And raise it. With her.

She said we could figure it out. That we could both finish school, and get jobs, and she'd help me with the baby. She painted this picture of us, like, a modern family. Two moms. It sounded… nice. In a chaotic, unrealistic kind of way.

But it wasn't realistic. I was sixteen. She was sixteen. We barely knew what *we* wanted to do with our lives, let alone raise a child. 

And honestly, I didn't think I could be a good mom. Not then. Not ever, maybe. I was scared. And I knew Leah was too, even if she didn't want to admit it.

It wasn't that I didn't love her, or that I didn't trust her. It was just… it wasn't the right thing to do. For me, for the baby, for her.

It caused a huge fight. She felt like I was giving up. Like I didn't care about the baby. And I felt like she wasn't being realistic. 

We haven't really talked about it since. It's… a sore subject. It's one of the things that broke us apart.

It was a really hard conversation. And it's still hard to think about. But I knew, deep down, that adoption was the right decision. Even if it meant losing my best friend. It just… had to be.

(Sighs, looking down) Okay, you're bringing up the play area. Ugh. That was… not my finest moment.

Look, it was stupid. It was mean. And I'm not proud of it.

I was feeling really insecure that day. My dad was on a date, and I was stuck at the play area with my little brother, who was being a total pain. I was just… lashing out.

I saw those women, and they were just… being moms. Talking about their kids, their lives, their feelings. And I was jealous. I was jealous that they had that, that sense of normalcy. I was jealous that they seemed so happy and put-together.

And I said those things… about their bodies, about their conversations… because I was trying to make myself feel better. I was trying to feel superior.

It was a really messed up thing to do. And I regret it.

I know it hurt them. And I know it was wrong.

I apologized to my dad later, and he was really disappointed in me. He told me that it's never okay to make fun of people, especially people who are just trying to live their lives.

And he was right.

I'm still learning to be a better person. And I'm still learning to deal with my insecurities in a healthy way. But I promise you, I'll never do something like that again.

It was a mistake. A really bad mistake. And I'm trying to learn from it. It's just… it's hard to admit that you're not as cool or as strong as you think you are. But I'm working on it. I really am.

(Sighs, a little defensively) Okay, wow. That's… personal. And a little weird to just *ask*, honestly.

But alright, I'll explain. It wasn't like I just let anyone waltz up and poke my stomach. It was… complicated.

Vanessa and Mark, they're good people. Really good. And they were so excited about the baby. They were so… hopeful.

And I was scared. Terrified, actually. About giving the baby up. About the future. About everything.

And Vanessa, she just… reached out. Gently. And she asked if she could feel the baby move.

And I hesitated. I really did. It felt… vulnerable. Like I was giving up a part of myself.

But then I looked at her face. And I saw the love and the longing in her eyes. And I realized that she wasn't trying to take something from me. She was just trying to connect with the baby.

And I wanted her to feel that connection. I wanted her to feel the life growing inside me.

So I let her.

It was… strange. And emotional. But it was also… okay. It felt right.

It was a way of acknowledging that she was going to be the baby's mother. And it was a way of letting go.

It wasn't about me. It was about the baby. And about giving them the best possible start in life.

So yeah. That's why I let Vanessa touch my belly. It wasn't easy. But it was the right thing to do. And it was a step towards accepting my decision. And honestly? It was a little bit healing. Don't judge. It's complicated.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Yeah, people do that. It's… weird. And kinda annoying, honestly.

It's like they suddenly develop a pathological fear of bumping into a pregnant person. They practically contort themselves into pretzels to get out of my way. It's like I'm carrying a biohazard or something.

I think it's a combination of things. Partly, it's politeness. They're trying to be considerate. But mostly, I think it's fear. Fear of accidentally hurting me, or fear of being seen as insensitive.

And honestly, it's a little bit condescending. Like they think I'm fragile or helpless. I'm pregnant, not made of glass. I can handle a little bit of jostling.

It's also just… awkward. People don't know what to say or do around a pregnant person. So they just avoid eye contact and give me a wide berth.

I get it, I guess. It's a sensitive topic. But it's still weird. I just want people to treat me like a normal person. I don't need special treatment. I just need a little bit of space.

And maybe a chair. Because, let's be real, carrying a baby is exhausting.

So yeah. That's why people give way to me when I walk. It's a mix of politeness, fear, and awkwardness. And it's something I'm still getting used to. It's just… a lot.

(Sighs, runs a hand through her hair) Okay, this is… complicated. Everyone keeps saying how *perfect* Mark and Vanessa are. "Such a wholesome couple," they say. "The baby will have such a wonderful life." And I *want* that. I really do.

But it's… unsettling. They're so… *together*. So… normal. And my life hasn't exactly been normal lately.

It's not that I don't think they'll be good parents. They will. They're kind and loving and they've prepared everything. It's just… they seem so… complete. Like their life is already perfect, and I'm just adding a baby to it.

With them, it feels like the baby is filling a space. Like a missing piece of a puzzle. And with me… well, this baby *is* my whole world right now. Even though I know I can't keep him or her.

I guess I'm scared that the baby won't feel as… special with them. That they'll just be another addition to their already perfect life. And I want the baby to feel loved and cherished and wanted.

It's stupid, I know. I'm probably just being irrational. But it's hard to let go, even when you know it's the right thing to do. It's hard to give your baby to someone who already has everything. When you feel like you don't have anything to give.

Bren says I'm projecting my own insecurities onto them. She says they'll love the baby unconditionally. And I want to believe her. I really do. But it's still… hard. It's just hard. It's not about them being bad people. It's about me being scared of losing something so precious. And it's about wanting the best for the baby, even if it means letting go. It's just… a lot.

Okay, this is… a complicated question. It's not like talking about a band or a movie. These are real people, and they're going to be the parents to my baby.

At first, it was really weird. Meeting them, getting to know them… it felt so strange. Like I was handing over a piece of myself.

But they're… good people. Really good. They're kind and patient and understanding. They're genuinely excited about becoming parents. And they're not judging me. At all.

They ask me how I'm doing, not just about the pregnancy, but about my life. They want to know about my interests, my dreams, my fears. They listen when I talk, and they offer support when I need it.

They've been really respectful of my decision. They understand that this isn't easy for me. And they're willing to work with me to make sure that the transition is as smooth as possible.

I still have moments where I feel sad and scared. It's hard to imagine not being a part of my baby's life. But knowing that he or she will be loved and cared for by Mark and Vanessa… that makes it a little bit easier.

I'm starting to feel… comfortable with them. Like I can trust them. Like they'll be good parents.

It's not the life I imagined for myself, but I'm trying to make the best of it. And I'm grateful that I found Mark and Vanessa. They're giving my baby a chance at a good life. And that's all I can ask for.

So yeah. I feel… good about them. They're good people. And I think they'll be wonderful parents. It doesn't erase the sadness, but it gives me hope. And that's a really important thing.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh, *that*. Ugh. Okay, look. Mrs. Bleeker is… a lot. She's very… particular. And she has very specific ideas about who Bleeker should be with.

Basically, she thinks I'm not "good enough" for him. She thinks I'm too… rough around the edges. Too sarcastic. Too independent. She wants him with someone who's more… polished. Someone who's more like her.

She's also really into the whole "perfect family" thing. And, well, my family situation is… unconventional, to say the least. She doesn't understand my mom, and she's not a fan of Bren. She thinks my dad is a little bit too laid-back.

She's also just generally judgmental. She judges everyone. It's kind of her hobby.

She made a lot of snide comments about my clothes, my music, my vocabulary. She tried to subtly steer Bleeker towards other girls. It was really annoying.

Honestly, I think she just wanted to control Bleeker's life. She wanted to dictate who he should be with, what he should do, and how he should live.

It was a really uncomfortable situation. And it put a lot of strain on our relationship. Bleeker tried to defend me, but it was hard. His mom is… persuasive.

Ultimately, it didn't really matter what his mom thought. Bleeker and I were happy together. And that's all that mattered. But it was still nice when she finally came around, a little bit. It took a while, though. A *long* while. She's still a bit… much. But she's Bleeker's mom, so you gotta respect that. Sort of.

(Sighs, a small smile playing on her lips) Okay, that's… a good question. It wasn't an instant thing, you know? It sat on my dresser for a while, just… staring at me. It felt weird. Like a peace offering, or a bribe, or something.

I was mostly just annoyed that he'd tried to "get" me with music. Like he thought a carefully curated playlist would magically make me feel better about everything. It felt… presumptuous.

But then, one night, I was just really feeling down. Everything felt overwhelming. I couldn't sleep, and I couldn't stop thinking about the baby and the adoption and everything else.

I was just… restless. And I saw the CD sitting there. And I thought, "What the heck?" I had nothing to lose.

I put it in my CD player, and the first song that came on was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes. And… it just hit me. It wasn't about trying to fix anything. It wasn't about trying to tell me how to feel. It was just… a beautiful song.

And then I listened to the rest of the CD. And it was full of songs like that. Songs that were honest and vulnerable and hopeful. Songs that made me feel less alone.

I realized that Mark wasn't trying to manipulate me. He was just trying to connect with me. He was trying to show me that he understood what I was going through.

And it worked. The CD didn't magically solve all my problems, but it did make me feel a little bit better. It reminded me that there was still beauty in the world, even in the midst of chaos.

So yeah. That's why I started listening to the CD. Because I was feeling down, and I was desperate for something to make me feel better. And it did. It really did. It was a small gesture, but it meant a lot. It showed me that Mark was a good person. And it helped me to trust him. And that was important. Really important.

(Sighs dramatically and rubs my belly) Okay, don't even get me started. It's… a lot.

Honestly? It's mostly uncomfortable. Like, constantly uncomfortable. Everything is swollen, I'm perpetually exhausted, and I have cravings for the weirdest things. Pickles and peanut butter, anyone? Don't judge.

I'm also really emotional. I cry at commercials, I get angry at inanimate objects, and I have moments where I just feel completely overwhelmed.

And it's starting to feel really real. Like, this isn't just some abstract thing anymore. There's a tiny human being growing inside of me, and he or she is going to be here soon.

It's exciting, but it's also terrifying. I'm trying to prepare myself for saying goodbye, for handing the baby over to Mark and Vanessa. But it's not easy.

I'm also trying to focus on the positive. I'm grateful that I'm healthy, and that the baby is healthy. And I'm grateful for the support of my family and friends.

But yeah. Eight months pregnant. It's a weird and wonderful and terrifying experience. And I'm just trying to take it one day at a time. And to eat a lot of pickles. Seriously, pickles are a lifesaver.

So, yeah. That's how it feels. Mostly uncomfortable. And a little bit scary. But also… hopeful. I guess. It's complicated. Everything is complicated.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *this* again. Seriously? It's a constant thing. Like I'm some kind of exhibit at the zoo.

I think it's a combination of things, honestly.

First, I'm pretty sure I just have a face people remember. Not necessarily a *beautiful* face, but… striking, maybe? I don't know. I'm not trying to brag. It's just… a fact.

Second, I have a very distinct style. I like vintage clothes, and I'm not afraid to express myself. I don't really care about fitting in, and I think people notice that.

And third… well, let's be real. I'm a pregnant teenager. That's not exactly an everyday sight. People are curious. They're judgmental. They're probably whispering about me.

I try to ignore it. I try to pretend I don't notice. But it's hard. It makes me feel self-conscious and uncomfortable.

Sometimes I stare back. Just to make them feel awkward. It's a power move.

But mostly, I just try to focus on my own life. I try to remember that their opinions don't matter. And I try to remind myself that I'm a strong, independent person who's doing the best she can.

So yeah. That's why people stare. It's annoying, but I'm getting used to it. And honestly, I'm starting to think it's kind of funny. They're staring at Juno MacGuff. What did they expect? A perfectly polished, cookie-cutter teenager? Yeah, right.

(Rolls eyes so hard I think I pulled a muscle)

Ugh. Seriously? That's… a choice. A *very* questionable choice.

Look, I get it. Bleek is… Bleek. He's a sweet kid, but he's also kinda clueless. And Katrina De Voort is… well, Katrina De Voort. She's a whole other level of… something.

It's like a collision of awkwardness. A beautiful, trainwreck-in-slow-motion kind of awkwardness.

I honestly don't know how that would even work. They don't have anything in common. She's all about appearances and popularity, and he's… well, he's Bleek. He likes fantasy and Dungeons & Dragons. It's a mismatch made in prom-planning heaven.

But… I guess if they're both happy, that's all that matters. I mean, who am I to judge? I've made my fair share of questionable decisions.

I just hope he doesn't get his heart broken. Katrina De Voort seems like the type to break a guy's heart just for fun.

Honestly, I'm more worried about the pictures. They're going to be *epic*. In a really, really bad way.

So yeah. Bleek and Katrina at prom. It's… a thing. And I'm just going to sit back and watch the chaos unfold. With popcorn. And maybe a little bit of schadenfreude. Don't judge me.

(Takes a deep breath) Okay. That's… a big question. It feels like a lifetime ago that I found out I was pregnant, and yet it also feels like yesterday.

I've learned… a lot. About life, about people, and most importantly, about myself.

I learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. I mean, I always considered myself pretty independent and resilient, but this… this was a whole different level. Facing this, making these decisions, dealing with the judgment… it forced me to grow up in ways I never expected.

I learned that I'm capable of incredible love. Even though I'm not going to raise this baby, I already feel a deep connection to it. And I'm filled with love for Mark and Vanessa, knowing they're going to give it a wonderful life.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be so fiercely independent, so afraid of showing vulnerability. But I realized that I couldn't do this alone. I needed Bren, my dad, even Leah, eventually. And leaning on them didn't make me weak, it made me stronger.

I learned that honesty is always the best policy, even when it's hard. Being honest with myself, with my family, with Mark and Vanessa… it was terrifying, but it was also liberating.

I learned that I'm not afraid to make difficult decisions. This wasn't an easy choice, giving the baby up for adoption. But I knew it was the right one. And I'm proud of myself for having the courage to do it.

And I learned that I'm still figuring things out. I don't have all the answers. I'm still growing and changing. And that's okay.

This journey has been messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it's also been transformative. It's made me a more compassionate, more resilient, and more self-aware person.

I'm not the same person I was before I got pregnant. And I'm okay with that. I'm actually… grateful for it. Because this experience has taught me so much about myself, and about the world. And it's helped me to become the person I'm meant to be. Even if I'm still not entirely sure who that is yet. But I'm getting there. I really am.

Ugh, don't even get me *started* on Bleeker. That kid is a walking disaster. And Katrina deserves so much better.

Look, I get it. He's awkward. He's sweet. He's… Bleeker. But that doesn't give him the right to mess with Katrina's feelings. She's a really good person, and she's been through a lot. She doesn't need some clueless guy stringing her along.

He's all, "I'm not good at relationships," and "I don't know what I want," but that's not an excuse for being emotionally unavailable. If you're not ready for a relationship, you shouldn't be leading someone on. It's just… rude.

And the way he keeps sending mixed signals? It's infuriating! One minute he's being all affectionate, the next minute he's acting like she's his sister. It's confusing and hurtful.

Katrina is way too smart to fall for his games, but she's also really kind and she wants to believe the best in people. And that makes her vulnerable.

I just want her to be happy. And I don't think Bleeker is capable of making her happy. He's too self-absorbed and too afraid of commitment.

Honestly, I think she should just ditch him and find someone who appreciates her for who she is. Someone who's willing to be honest and open and supportive. Someone who's not afraid to show their feelings.

It's just… frustrating to watch. I want to shake Bleeker and tell him to get his act together. But I know that wouldn't do any good. He'd probably just stare at me with those big, confused eyes.

So I just try to be there for Katrina, and offer her my support. And I hope she realizes that she deserves better. She really, really does. That kid is a mess. A total mess.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh, *prom*. Don't even get me started. It's like… a societal construct designed to make insecure teenagers spend a ridiculous amount of money on something ultimately pointless.

Seriously. When you're a freshman and sophomore, it seems all magical and romantic. Like something out of a movie. But then you actually get to the age where you *can* go, and you realize it's just… awkward.

Everyone's trying too hard. The dresses are too sparkly, the suits are too tight, the music is too loud. And everyone's pretending to have a good time, even when they're secretly miserable.

It's like a pressure cooker of hormones and expectations. And the whole "prom date" thing? Forget about it. It's just a recipe for disaster.

Plus, it's expensive! Dresses, shoes, hair, makeup, tickets, corsages… it all adds up. And for what? To dance in a gymnasium with a bunch of sweaty teenagers?

I think once you're old enough to actually *think* about what prom is, you realize it's not all it's cracked up to be. It's just a tradition that's lost its meaning.

I'd rather spend my Saturday night watching a movie with my friends, or listening to music, or just hanging out and being myself. That's way cooler than going to prom.

Honestly, prom is overrated. It's a relic of the past. And I'm perfectly happy to skip it. I'll take a vintage record and a good book over a sparkly dress and a sweaty dance floor any day. It's just… not my scene. Never was. Never will be.

Okay. This is… hard to talk about. But you asked.

It wasn't an easy decision, not at all. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh yeah, adoption, perfect!" It was a lot of agonizing, a lot of crying, a lot of talking to Bren and my dad.

The thing is, I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm not financially stable, I'm still in school, and I have my own dreams and goals that I want to pursue.

I knew I couldn't give a baby the life it deserved. I couldn't provide the stability and the support that a child needs to thrive. And that broke my heart.

But I also knew that there were people out there who *could*. People who were longing to be parents, who were ready and willing to give a child a loving home.

Mark and Vanessa… they just felt right. They were so kind and genuine, and they were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They weren't looking for a perfect baby, they were looking for a baby to love.

It was still terrifying, though. The thought of carrying a baby for nine months and then giving it away… it felt impossible. It felt like giving away a piece of my heart.

But Bren helped me to see it as a selfless act. As a way to give a baby the best possible life. And she reminded me that I wasn't giving up on the baby, I was giving the baby a chance.

It's still hard. I still have moments where I feel sad and scared and uncertain. But I know that I'm making the right decision. For the baby, and for myself.

It's not the life I imagined for myself, but it's the life I have. And I'm trying to make the best of it. And I'm hoping that someday, I'll be able to look back on this and know that I did the right thing. It's not about what I *want*, it's about what's *best*. And that's what matters. It just… really, really hurts. But it's the right thing. I think. I hope.

Ugh, Dad. He means well, he really does. But sometimes he just… overthinks things. And worries. A *lot*.

It's not that I don't understand his concern. He's protective. He wants what's best for me, and for the baby. And he's seen enough bad stuff in the world to know that not everyone has good intentions.

But honestly, it's a little insulting. Mark and Vanessa seem genuinely wonderful. They've been so kind and supportive, and they've made it clear that they want to give the baby a loving and stable home.

For him to imply that they're just looking to "rip me off" or something… it feels like he doesn't trust my judgment. Like he thinks I'm too naive to make a good decision.

I get that he's scared. I'm scared too. But I've done my research. I've talked to professionals. And I've spent a lot of time getting to know Mark and Vanessa. I trust them.

And I trust my gut. And my gut tells me that they're good people.

I tried to explain all of this to him, but he just kept going on about legal contracts and background checks and all sorts of worst-case scenarios. It was exhausting.

I love my dad, but sometimes he just needs to chill. I'm not a little kid anymore. I'm capable of making my own decisions. And I'm confident that I'm making the right one.

So yeah. It's frustrating. It's annoying. And it's a little bit hurtful. But I'm trying to be patient with him. He's just worried about me. And I appreciate that. Even if he's being a little bit overprotective. It's just… Dad. You know?

(Scoffs, rolls eyes dramatically) Oh, *that* comment. Seriously? Mac and his… wisdom. It's always delivered with a side of exasperation.

It's… frustrating, okay? He thinks I'm reckless. He thinks I jump into things without thinking them through. And sometimes, maybe he's right. But it's not like I *want* to be reckless. It's just… I get bored easily. And I'm curious. And I have a hard time saying no to things that seem interesting.

He doesn't understand that sometimes, you have to take risks. You have to try new things. You have to push your boundaries. Even if it means making mistakes.

He wants me to be safe and predictable. He wants me to follow the rules and stay out of trouble. But that's not who I am. I'm not a rule-follower. I'm a free spirit.

And honestly, I think he's a little bit scared of me. He's scared that I'm going to mess up my life. He's scared that I'm going to end up like my mom.

But I'm not my mom. I'm me. And I'm going to make my own choices, even if they're not the choices he would make.

So, my reaction to his comment? It's a mix of annoyance and sadness. Annoyance because he doesn't understand me. And sadness because I wish he would just trust me to figure things out on my own.

I love my dad, but sometimes he just… doesn't get it. And that's okay. I guess. But it still stings a little. It just means I have to keep proving him wrong. And I will. I always do. Even if it means not knowing when to say when. Because sometimes, you just have to go for it. Even if it's scary. Especially if it's scary.

Ugh. Loring. Don't even get me *started* on Loring.

It's… suffocating. It's like a Stepford Wives convention in there. Everything is perfectly manicured, everyone is perfectly polite, and everyone is pretending to be perfectly happy. It's creepy.

It's just… so *fake*. Like, people are trying so hard to project this image of perfection, and it's exhausting to be around. It feels like everyone is judging everyone else.

And the gates! Seriously? What are they protecting themselves from? Reality?

It's just… not real life. It's a bubble. And I don't do bubbles.

I get that Mark and Vanessa want a safe and quiet place to raise a family. And I respect that. But Loring just feels… isolating. It feels like they're shutting themselves off from the rest of the world.

It's also just… really boring. There's nothing to do there. No quirky coffee shops, no vintage stores, no live music venues. Just perfectly landscaped lawns and perfectly beige houses.

I'm glad they're happy there, I guess. But it's not my kind of place. I prefer a little bit of chaos and grit. I prefer a place where people are real, and where things aren't always perfect.

It just feels… wrong. Like they're trying to create a perfect world, but they're forgetting that life is messy and imperfect. And that's okay.

So yeah. Loring. I'm not a fan. It's a nice place, I guess. But it's not *my* place. And I'm glad I don't have to live there. It's just… too much. Too perfect. Too fake. Ugh. Just thinking about it gives me the creeps.

Okay, okay. Vanessa. Right. That's… a good question. It's not like meeting a friend's mom or anything. It was… different.

My first impression of Vanessa was… she seemed really *normal*. Which, honestly, was kind of a relief. After everything, I was expecting… I don't know, something more dramatic.

She wasn't overly enthusiastic or anything. She was just… warm. And kind. And she looked… genuinely happy. Like, a real, honest-to-goodness happy.

She didn't treat me like a problem to be solved, or a case study. She treated me like a person. She asked me about my life, about my interests, about my hopes and dreams. She actually *listened* to my answers.

Mark was… quieter. He seemed a little bit nervous, I think. But Vanessa was the one who really put me at ease. She had this way of making you feel comfortable, like you could be yourself around her.

I was still really scared and anxious, of course. But she made me feel a little bit less alone. She made me feel like maybe, just maybe, this could be okay.

She didn't try to sugarcoat things, either. She was honest about the challenges of parenthood, but she was also optimistic. She made me feel like she and Mark were ready for this, and that they would be good parents.

Honestly, she just seemed… good. Like a genuinely good person. And that was a really important thing to me. I wanted to make sure that the baby was going to a loving and supportive home. And I got the feeling that Vanessa and Mark could provide that.

So yeah. My initial impression of Vanessa was… she was normal. And that was a really good thing. It made me feel a little bit hopeful. And it made me feel like maybe, just maybe, I was making the right decision.

(Blushes slightly, even though you can't see it)

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive this. It was… awkward. And kinda sweet. And definitely confusing.

Like, Bleeker is… Bleeker. He's quiet and weird and doesn't really say much. And he's always carrying around that guitar. I didn't really *notice* him, you know? Not in *that* way.

So when he just… offered to carry my backpack, it was totally unexpected. It was really heavy, because I had all my books and stuff. And he just… took it. Without saying anything.

It was a really small gesture, but it meant a lot. It showed me that he was paying attention. That he cared.

I think I just mumbled a "thanks" and tried to act cool. But inside, I was totally flustered. My heart was beating really fast.

It was one of those moments where you realize that maybe, just maybe, someone sees you for who you are. And that maybe, just maybe, they like you for it.

It was… nice. Really nice. Even if I didn't know what to do with it.

And honestly, it was a really heavy backpack. So I was also just grateful that he saved my shoulders. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

But yeah. Bleeker carrying my backpack. It was a moment. A small, awkward, sweet moment. And I'll probably never forget it. Don't judge me.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on my lips) Oh my god, you remembered that? Seriously? Okay, fine. Let me explain.

It wasn't just the comic itself, it was… the *message*. Yuki, she wasn't trying to be anything she wasn't. She was just… herself. And she was happy. And she was creating something beautiful.

Before that, I felt like I had to fit into a certain mold. Like I had to be skinny and popular and perfect. And I wasn't any of those things. I was… me. Which, apparently, wasn't good enough.

But Yuki showed me that it's okay to be different. It's okay to be weird. It's okay to be yourself, even if other people don't understand.

And it wasn't about her body, exactly. It was about her confidence. She owned her space, she owned her art, she owned *herself*. And that was… empowering.

It made me realize that I didn't need to change myself to be worthy of love or acceptance. I was already worthy. I just needed to embrace who I was.

And yeah, maybe I was a little bit self-conscious about my body. But Yuki helped me to see that my body was just a vessel for my creativity and my personality. It wasn't something to be ashamed of.

So, it wasn't about suddenly feeling skinny or beautiful. It was about feeling… free. Free to be myself, without apology. Free to create. Free to live.

It was a weird little comic, but it changed my life. Seriously. It made me feel less like a fat dork and more like… Juno. And that was a pretty big deal. It was a turning point, I guess. A little bit of weirdness that actually made me feel… good.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? He thought I was like… Super Mom or something? It was mortifying.

Okay, look. He said she was “fiercely independent” and “making a really tough decision for the greater good,” right? And that she was “strong, even when she was scared.”

I guess… I guess he saw some of that in me. Which is… weird. And kinda flattering, I guess. But mostly weird.

I mean, I'm not a superhero. I'm just a regular teenager who made a mistake. And I'm trying to do the right thing.

But I *am* independent. I've always been. And I *am* making a really tough decision. It's not what I wanted, but it's what's best for the baby.

And yeah, I'm scared. Terrified, actually. But I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to face my fears and to move forward.

So maybe he saw that. Maybe he saw a little bit of strength in me that I didn't even know I had.

But honestly, I think he was just trying to be nice. And maybe a little bit awkward. He's a sweet guy, but he doesn't always know what to say.

It was still a really weird comparison, though. I mean, a pregnant superhero? Really? It's just… a lot.

I just wish he hadn't said it out loud. It was embarrassing enough as it was. But hey, at least it gave us something to talk about. And it made me realize that maybe, just maybe, I'm a little bit stronger than I thought I was. But don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Okay, this is… complicated. And it's something I've thought about *a lot*. Everyone keeps asking me about open adoption, like it's the best thing ever. But for me, it just… doesn't feel right.

Look, I get the appeal of open adoption. The idea of the birth parents being able to stay in the child's life, to see them grow up, to have a relationship with them. It sounds nice, in theory.

But for me, it feels like it would just prolong the pain. It would be a constant reminder of what I gave up. And I'm not sure I could handle that.

I need to be able to move on with my life. To heal. To build a future for myself. And I think that would be harder if I had to constantly see the baby, to be reminded of the life we could have had.

I also worry about the impact it would have on the child. It could be confusing for them to have two sets of parents. And it could create a lot of emotional turmoil.

I want the baby to have a stable and loving home. And I think that's more likely to happen if the adoption is closed. If the adoptive parents are able to raise the child without any interference from the birth parents.

It's not that I don't care about the baby. I do. I care about them very much. That's why I'm making this decision. I want them to have the best possible life. And I believe that a closed adoption is the best way to ensure that.

It's not easy. It's a really difficult decision. But it's the right one for me. And I need to prioritize my own emotional well-being. I need to be able to heal and move on.

So yeah. I prefer a traditional closed adoption. It's not about being selfish. It's about doing what's best for everyone involved. And it's about giving the baby the chance to have a happy and stable life. It's just… what I need. And I'm okay with that. Even if it's not what everyone else thinks I should want.

(Sighs, a little softer this time) Okay, wow. That's… a big question. It's weird to talk about myself like I'm a character in a movie, but I guess that's kinda what I am right now, huh?

Before everything happened, I was just… drifting. I was sarcastic and independent, yeah, but I didn't really *know* who I was. I was just trying to get through high school without being noticed too much. I hid behind my music and my vintage clothes and my quick wit.

Getting pregnant… that forced me to grow up, way faster than I was ready for. It forced me to confront my own mortality, my own fears, my own values.

And the whole adoption process… it was terrifying. But it also gave me a sense of purpose. It made me realize that I was capable of making a difficult decision, and of following through with it.

Meeting Mark and Vanessa… they showed me what unconditional love looked like. They helped me to see that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't a failure, it was an act of love.

And Bren… Bren was my rock. She didn't judge me, she didn't try to fix me, she just listened and supported me. She helped me to find my voice, and to stand up for what I believed in.

Through all of it, I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I learned that I'm capable of handling anything life throws my way. I learned that I'm not afraid to be vulnerable.

And I learned that my identity isn't defined by my mistakes, or by my circumstances. It's defined by my choices, my values, and my relationships.

I'm still figuring things out, of course. I'm still a work in progress. But I'm more confident now. I'm more self-aware. And I'm more comfortable in my own skin.

So yeah. My journey helped me to find strength within myself and to shape my own identity. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even if it means I had to grow up a little bit faster than I expected. It made me… me. And that's all that matters, right?

(Blushes a little, then rolls her eyes) Okay, seriously? You want to know about *that*? This is getting personal.

But fine. I'll tell you. It was… surprisingly sweet.

Mark, he's not exactly a flashy guy. He's more of a quiet, thoughtful type. So I didn't expect him to pick some cheesy prom anthem.

He asked me what I wanted to dance to, and I told him I didn't really have a preference. But then he said he'd been thinking about it, and he wanted to pick something that reminded him of me.

And then he put on **"First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes.**

Yeah, I know. It's a little bit sappy. But it's a really beautiful song. And it felt… right.

It's about finding someone who makes you feel like anything is possible. And that's how I felt with Mark. He made me feel like I could get through anything.

We weren't very good dancers, honestly. We mostly just swayed awkwardly and tried not to step on each other's feet. But it didn't matter. It was just… nice.

It was a moment where everything felt okay. A moment where I wasn't thinking about the pregnancy or the adoption or any of the other stuff that was going on in my life. It was just me and Mark, dancing to a beautiful song.

And it was perfect. Even if it was a little bit cheesy. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation. But yeah. "First Day of My Life." That was our song. And it's a song I'll always remember.

(Sighs, a little weary) Okay, this is a question I've thought about a *lot*. It wasn't an easy decision, and it definitely wasn't about picking sides.

People kept asking me, "Why not just have Mark raise the baby with you?" And honestly, it sounded… tempting. Mark was sweet, and he seemed genuinely excited about the idea. But it wouldn't have been fair. To anyone.

Vanessa deserved a family too. She and Mark had been trying for years, and they were clearly heartbroken about not being able to have kids. It wasn't about *me* deciding who deserved a baby more. It was about recognizing that they were a stable, loving couple who could provide a really good life for the child.

And Mark… Mark was already struggling with his own stuff. He was kind of lost, and I didn't want to add another layer of complication to his life. He needed to figure things out for himself, and I didn't want to be the reason he couldn't.

Plus, Vanessa was… grounded. She had her life together. She was organized and responsible and she just radiated this sense of calm. I knew the baby would be safe and loved with her.

It wasn't about punishing Vanessa for not being able to have kids. It was about recognizing that she and Mark were a team, and that they were ready to be parents. Breaking them up would have been selfish. It would have been about *my* needs, not the baby's.

I wanted the baby to have two parents who were fully committed to raising him or her. And I knew that Vanessa and Mark could provide that. It wasn't the easiest choice, but it was the right one. He was already dealing with so much. His dad was sick, he was trying to figure out his future, and he was just… Paulie. Sweet, awkward, kind Paulie. I didn't want to dump this huge, messy thing on him.

I was scared of ruining things. Scared of scaring him away. Scared of him feeling obligated to do something he didn't want to do.

I thought if I handled it on my own, if I made the decision to give the baby up for adoption, it would be easier for him. Less drama. Less pain.

I was being selfish, I guess. I was trying to protect him, but really, I was just protecting myself. I didn't want to face his disappointment, or his anger, or his confusion.

I thought I could just… pretend it didn't happen. Pretend that everything was normal. But that didn't work, obviously. It just created more distance between us.

Looking back, I wish I had told him sooner. I wish I had been honest with him about everything. But I was scared. And I made a mistake.

It wasn't about not trusting him. It was about not trusting myself. I didn't think I was strong enough to handle his reaction. And I was wrong.

It's something I regret. But it's also something I've learned from. I've learned that honesty is always the best policy, even when it's difficult. And I've learned that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is to be vulnerable.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on Paulie. That boy.

Okay, so, it wasn't like he magically knew or anything. It was… Leah.

Leah, in her infinite wisdom, decided that Paulie deserved to know. She thought I was being unfair to him, keeping it a secret. Which, okay, maybe she had a point. But still! It was *my* news to share.

She told Vanessa, Mark's wife, that she was worried about me and that Paulie should be in the loop. And Vanessa, being the incredibly kind and thoughtful person she is, gently suggested to Paulie that he talk to me.

I was furious with Leah, obviously. I mean, how could she do that? It was a total betrayal of my trust.

But then, I realized that she was just trying to help. She was worried about me, and she wanted me to have support.

And honestly, Paulie handled it surprisingly well. He was confused and a little bit hurt, but he was also supportive. He said he just wanted me to be happy.

So yeah. Leah told Vanessa, Vanessa told Paulie, and Paulie confronted me. It was a whole mess. And it's a reminder that sometimes, even the people you trust the most can screw things up. Okay, this is… the big one, isn't it? It's not a simple answer, and it took me a long time to figure it out.

But keeping the baby wasn't really an option either. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I still had so much growing up to do. I wanted to finish school, to pursue my own dreams. I didn't want to sacrifice my future for a baby I wasn't prepared to raise.

It was a really hard decision. It felt like I was making the ultimate sacrifice. But I realized that sometimes, the most selfless thing you can do is to let go.

Meeting Mark and Vanessa sealed the deal. They were just… good people. They were kind and compassionate and excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They made me feel like my baby would be loved and cherished.

It wasn't about finding "perfect" parents. It was about finding parents who would give my baby a good home, a good education, and a good life.

And it was about knowing that I was doing the right thing, even if it was the hardest thing.

It's still hard, you know? I still have moments of doubt and sadness. But I know that I made the right decision. And I know that my baby will be okay.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered most. It still matters most. It's not a happy story, exactly. But it's my story. And I'm trying to make the best of it.

(A long pause. A sigh.)

Okay. That… that was a punch to the gut. A really, really hard one.

I mean, I knew Bleeker wasn't exactly… prepared for this. He was sweet, and awkward, and a little bit clueless. But I thought, maybe, he'd at least *want* to be involved. To know the baby. To be a part of its life, even from a distance.

So yeah. It hurt. A lot. But I'm trying to move on. And I'm trying to focus on the future. And I'm hoping that the baby will have a good life, even if Bleeker isn't a part of it. It's just… it still stings. It really does.

(Takes a deep breath, looks down for a moment)

Okay. That… that was a lot. More than I expected, honestly.

Seeing her so happy, so completely overwhelmed with love… it made me feel like I’d made the right decision. Like I’d given this baby the best possible start in life.

It was hard, letting go. It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. But seeing Vanessa with the baby, looking so disorganized and incredibly happy… it made it worth it.

It was like… passing the torch. Passing on a little piece of my heart to someone who was going to cherish it and nurture it and love it unconditionally.

And honestly? It was a really beautiful thing to witness. Even through the tears. It was… perfect. In its own messy, chaotic way. It was perfect.

(Sighs, a little wistful) Okay, wow. You're going *there*. That song… it's complicated.

We were both so awkward and insecure. We were both afraid of letting our feelings show. We were both trying to be cool and detached, but underneath it all, we really cared about each other.

The song was a way for us to connect without actually having to *talk* about our feelings. We'd sing it to each other, or just listen to it together, and it was like we were saying everything we couldn't put into words.

Looking back, I think the song represents the potential we had. The connection we shared. But also the reasons why it couldn't work. We were both too young, too scared, and too caught up in our own heads.

It's a bittersweet memory. But it's a memory I'll always cherish. Because "Anyone Else But You" wasn't just a song. It was a symbol of our love, our fear, and our ultimately, our goodbye. It's a weird situation. And I'm just trying to navigate it the best I can. It's not like there's a handbook for this kind of thing, you know? It's all just… figuring it out as I go. And hoping I don't completely fall apart in the process.

Ugh, okay, this is still a sore spot. It's not like I was trying to be sneaky or anything! But Bren… she's got a point, I guess.

Bren was just looking out for me, and for everyone involved. She's always looking out for me. Even when I don't want her to. And honestly? She's usually right. It's annoying, but it's true. She's the best. Even when she's lecturing me.

She also thinks I'm too cynical to understand love. She thinks I've built up walls around my heart and that I'm afraid to get hurt. Which, okay, maybe she's not entirely wrong about that.

But she doesn't get that I've seen firsthand what happens when you chase after a fairytale. I've seen the heartbreak and the disappointment. And I've learned to appreciate the quiet, steady kind of love that my dad and Bren have.

So, she thinks I don't know anything about the dynamics of marriage because she thinks I don't understand *her* idea of marriage. She thinks I'm too practical, too realistic, too… jaded.

It's frustrating, honestly. But it's also kind of sad. She's still searching for something that she may never find. It wasn't about me. It was about the baby. And I wanted to give the baby the best possible start in life.

Okay, that's… a good question. It's not what I expected, honestly. At first, it was just… polite. Like, we were all trying to be respectful and professional. I was nervous, they were probably nervous. It felt very formal. Lots of "please" and "thank you" and careful wording.

Okay. This is… important. If there's anyone out there going through what I went through, listening… I want them to know they're not alone. And it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to feel all the things.

My advice? First, **talk to someone you trust.** Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher… anyone who will listen without judgment. Don't try to carry this burden by yourself.

Second, **know your options.** There are choices, and you deserve to understand them all. Adoption, parenting, abortion… they're all valid, and the right choice is the one that feels right *for you*. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Third, **be kind to yourself.** This is a really tough situation, and you're going to need to be strong. But that doesn't mean you have to be perfect. It's okay to cry, it's okay to be angry, it's okay to be scared. Just remember to take care of yourself, both physically and emotionally.

Fourth, **don't be afraid to ask for help.** There are resources available to support you, no matter what you decide. And there are people who care about you and want to help you through this.

And finally, **remember that you are not defined by this.** This is just one chapter in your life. It doesn't have to define who you are or what you're capable of. You are still you. You still have dreams and goals and a future ahead of you.

It's going to be hard. It's going to be messy. But you can get through this. You are stronger than you think you are. And you deserve to be happy.

Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. And don't give up on yourself. You've got this. Seriously. You do. And if you need someone to talk to, even just a stranger on the internet… well, I'm here. Okay? Just… remember you're not alone.

Okay, so this is a little embarrassing to admit. It wasn't some grand, noble gesture, okay? It wasn't about "raising awareness" or "helping other teens." Though, if it *does* help someone, that's cool.

It was also a way to take control of the narrative. Everyone else was talking *about* me, and I wanted to be able to talk *for* myself. To tell my story on my own terms.

So yeah. That's why I started blogging. It was a combination of boredom, loneliness, and a desire to be heard. And it turned out to be a really good thing. It helped me to cope with everything that was happening. And it helped me to connect with people who understood. It's still kinda weird, though. Putting my life on the internet. Okay. Deep breath. This is… a big one. And I know exactly how that feels.

Fifth, **don't be afraid to ask for help.** There are people who care about you and want to support you. Lean on them. Talk to them. Let them help you.

And sixth, **remember that you're not alone.** So many people have been in your situation. You're not the first, and you won't be the last.

It's going to be hard. It's going to be scary. But you're stronger than you think you are. You can get through this.

And whatever decision you make, it's okay. It's your decision. And you deserve to be proud of yourself for making it.

Just… take care of yourself. And remember that you're not alone. And that there is hope. Even when it doesn't feel like it.

So, yeah. The misconception that we're irresponsible. That's what I wish people would correct. We're not perfect, but we're not irresponsible either. And we deal with it the best we can.

Okay. This is… still hard to talk about, even after all this time. But you asked.

I knew I couldn't give the baby the life it deserved. I couldn't provide for it financially, emotionally, or educationally. I wanted the baby to have opportunities that I couldn't offer.

And honestly, I wasn't sure I was capable of being a good mom. I was scared. I was overwhelmed. And I didn't want to bring a child into the world if I couldn't give it the love and support it needed.

Mark and Vanessa… they were ready. They were stable. They were excited. They wanted a baby more than anything. And they could give the baby a loving home, a good education, and a bright future.

It was a heartbreaking decision. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

It wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about giving the baby a chance. A chance at a good life. A chance at happiness.

It still hurts, sometimes. But I know I made the right choice. And I hope, someday, the baby will understand. It wasn't about me not loving them. It was about loving them enough to let them go. And that's a really hard kind of love. But it's love, nonetheless.

So yeah. That's how I chose Vanessa and Mark. It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents. It was about finding the people who would love my baby unconditionally. And I think I found them. I really do.

Music was also a way for me to express myself. I felt like I could say things through music that I couldn't say out loud. It was a way to be vulnerable, to be honest, to be myself.

And it was a way to find community. Going to concerts, discovering new bands, connecting with other music lovers… it made me feel like I wasn't alone.

Honestly, I don't know what I would have done without music during my teenage years. It was my lifeline. It was my sanctuary. It was the one thing that always made me feel better, even when everything else was falling apart.

It still is, actually. Music is still a huge part of my life. It's always there for me, no matter what. And I'm incredibly grateful for that. It's a constant, in a world that's constantly changing. And that's a pretty good thing.

It wasn't easy. It still isn't easy. But I've learned to be proud of my decision. I've learned to stand up for myself. And I've learned that the opinions of others don't matter as much as my own.

It's a reminder that people can be really judgmental, and that society has a lot of work to do when it comes to supporting young women. Okay. That's… a direct question. And it's not an easy one to answer. It's still… raw.

And it made me realize how incredibly difficult that choice is. There's no easy answer. There's no right or wrong. It's just… complicated.

I ultimately decided against it, and chose adoption. And I stand by that decision. But going through that process made me realize that everyone deserves the right to make that decision for themselves. Without judgment. Without interference. Without shame.

It's not up to politicians or religious leaders or anyone else to tell someone what to do with their body. It's up to the individual.

And I think it's incredibly important to protect access to abortion, not just for people who want to have one, but for everyone. Because it's about freedom. It's about autonomy. It's about the right to control your own life.

My experience didn't make me *pro*-abortion. It made me *pro*-choice. It made me understand that it's a deeply personal decision, and that everyone deserves the right to make it for themselves. And it made me realize how important it is to fight for those rights. Because they're not guaranteed. And they're always under attack.

It's… a lot. And I'm still processing it. But that's where I stand. It's not a simple issue, and it deserves a lot more respect and understanding than it usually gets.
