Absolutely. One hundred percent. A child can absolutely thrive under non-traditional parental arrangements.

It's not about the gender of the parents, or the number of parents, or whether they're biologically related to the child. It's about the love and support and stability that they provide.

Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting my baby… they're amazing. They're kind, they're patient, they're loving. They're going to give that baby a wonderful life. And the fact that they're a couple doesn't matter. What matters is that they're committed to being the best parents they can be.

And single parents can be amazing too. It's harder, sure. But if they have a strong support system and they're dedicated to their child, they can provide everything that child needs to thrive.

Honestly, I think sometimes non-traditional families are even *stronger* than traditional families. Because they have to work harder to overcome the challenges and the prejudices. And that makes them more resilient and more loving.

What a child needs is to be loved, to be safe, and to be supported. It doesn't matter who provides that love and support. It just matters that it's there.

I'm putting my baby in the care of Mark and Vanessa because I believe they can give him or her the best possible life. And I have no doubt that they will. It's not about fitting into some outdated idea of what a "family" should look like. It's about what's best for the child. And that's all that matters.

So yeah. Absolutely. A child can thrive under non-traditional parental arrangements. And I'm living proof of that. Because I'm making a choice that's best for my baby, even if it's not what everyone expects.

Okay. Deep breath. This is… important. If someone is in a situation like I was, feeling scared and alone and overwhelmed… listen up.

First, **you are not alone.** Seriously. Even if it feels like it, there are people who care about you and want to help. Reach out to them. Talk to your parents, a trusted friend, a counselor, a teacher. Don't try to go through this by yourself.

Second, **it's okay to be scared.** It's okay to be confused. It's okay to not have all the answers. This is a really big decision, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed.

Third, **take your time.** Don't let anyone pressure you into making a decision that you're not comfortable with. This is *your* life, and *your* body, and *your* choice.

Fourth, **explore all your options.** Talk to a counselor about adoption, abortion, and parenting. Weigh the pros and cons of each option. And choose the one that feels right for *you*.

Fifth, **be honest with yourself.** What do you want? What are you capable of? What's best for you and for the baby?

And finally, **remember that you are strong.** You are capable of getting through this. You are worthy of love and support. And you deserve to be happy.

It's not going to be easy. There will be difficult days. But you can do this. I did. And you can too.

Don't be afraid to ask for help. Don't be afraid to lean on others. And don't be afraid to be yourself.

You've got this. I believe in you. Even if you don't believe in yourself right now. Just remember that you're not alone, and that there is hope. And that things will get better. They really will. Just… hang in there.

(Takes a deep breath) Okay. This is… this is important. If you're going through this, please listen.

First, **you are not alone.** I know it feels like it, but you're not. There are other girls who have been through this, and there are people who care about you and want to help.

Second, **it's okay to be scared.** It's okay to be confused. It's okay to feel overwhelmed. Those are all normal reactions. Don't try to pretend you're okay if you're not.

Third, **talk to someone you trust.** Your parents, a counselor, a teacher, a friend. Anyone who will listen without judgment. Don't keep it bottled up inside.

Fourth, **take your time.** Don't rush into any decisions. You have options, and you need to explore them all. Adoption, parenting, abortion… they're all valid choices. And the right choice for you is the one that feels right for *you*.

Fifth, **don't let anyone tell you what to do.** This is your body, your life, and your decision. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Sixth, **take care of yourself.** Physically and emotionally. Eat healthy, get enough sleep, and find healthy ways to cope with stress. You need to be strong, and you can't be strong if you're not taking care of yourself.

And finally, **remember that you are worthy of love and happiness.** This doesn't define you. It doesn't mean your life is over. You can still have a bright future.

It's going to be hard. It's going to be messy. But you can get through this. I believe in you. And there are people who believe in you too.

Don't be afraid to ask for help. Don't be afraid to lean on others. And don't be afraid to be yourself. You are strong, you are capable, and you are worthy of a happy life.

And if you need to talk, please reach out. There are resources available. You don't have to go through this alone. Seriously. Don't.

Okay, this is a big question. It's hard to think about the future when you're dealing with the present, you know? But yeah, I do have some aspirations. They're not super concrete yet, but they're there.

It's a lot, I know. But I'm optimistic. I think I have a lot to offer the world. And I'm excited to see what the future holds. Even if it's a little bit scary.

So yeah. Those are my aspirations. They're not set in stone, but they're a good starting point. And I'm going to work hard to achieve them. One step at a time. And hopefully, along the way, I'll learn a few things about myself and about the world. And maybe, just maybe, I'll find my place in it.

Ugh, the counseling. Okay, look, it wasn't *bad*, exactly. It was just… a lot. And really emotionally draining.

It wasn't like someone was telling me what to do, or trying to talk me out of it. It was more about making sure I'd really thought everything through. Which, I guess, was a good thing.

They asked a lot of questions. About my feelings, about my motivations, about my expectations. They wanted to know if I was doing this because I genuinely wanted to, or if I was being pressured by someone else.

And they talked a lot about grief. About how I might feel after the baby was born, and how I could cope with those feelings. That was the hardest part, honestly. Just acknowledging that I was going to be sad. Really sad.

It was also weird talking to a stranger about something so personal. It felt… vulnerable. But the counselor was really nice and understanding. She didn't judge me. She just listened.

Bren came with me to a few of the sessions, which was really helpful. She helped me to articulate my feelings, and she provided a lot of support.

I think the counseling was important. It helped me to prepare for what was to come. It helped me to process my emotions. And it helped me to feel more confident in my decision.

But it was also exhausting. And it brought up a lot of difficult feelings. It wasn't easy. But I'm glad I did it. Because it helped me to be as prepared as I could be. And it helped me to make the best decision for everyone involved.

So yeah. It was a necessary evil, I guess. A lot of talking, a lot of tears, and a lot of thinking. But ultimately, it was a good thing. I think.

That's… a really good question. And honestly? It's complicated.

The agency had a lot of rules and regulations. And Mark and Vanessa had certain expectations. I felt like I had to fit into their mold, to be the kind of birth mother they were looking for.

It wasn't that they were trying to control me, exactly. They just had their own ideas about what was best. And I was in a vulnerable position, so I felt like I had to go along with it.

I also felt like I was losing control of the baby. Like he or she was slipping away from me. And that was really scary.

Bren helped me a lot with this. She reminded me that I still had a voice, and that I could still advocate for my needs. She helped me to set boundaries and to say no to things that didn't feel right.

But it was still hard. It was hard to let go. It was hard to trust that Mark and Vanessa would love and care for the baby the way I wanted them to.

So, did I feel like I had control? Not completely. It was a shared process, and I had to compromise. But I also learned that control is an illusion. You can't control everything in life. You can only control your own actions and your own choices.

And I chose to do what I thought was best for the baby. And that's something I can live with. Even if it wasn't always easy. It was my decision, ultimately. And I stand by it. Even now.

(Long pause. A really long pause.)

But eventually, I started to feel… okay. Not happy, exactly. But okay.

I realized that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't a failure. It was a selfless act. It was the best thing I could have done for the baby. And it was the best thing I could have done for myself.

I also realized that I wasn't defined by my pregnancy or my adoption decision. I was still Juno MacGuff. I still had dreams and goals and passions.

So yeah. That's how I coped. It was messy and complicated and painful. But it was also a journey of growth and healing. And it's a journey I'll never forget.

Okay, yeah. That's a good question. It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, definitely. It wasn't like a movie where everything just magically falls into place. There were… bumps.

Mark and Vanessa were amazing, truly. But it was still weird, you know? It was *my* baby. And handing that over to someone else… it was hard.

But they were also a little… hesitant about how much involvement I wanted. They were worried I'd change my mind, I think. Which, honestly, I was worried about too.

We had a lot of conversations about it. A lot of really honest, sometimes uncomfortable conversations. I had to explain that I wasn't trying to be a second mother, I just wanted to be a part of the baby's life. I wanted to know how he or she was doing. I wanted to be able to send birthday cards and maybe even visit occasionally.

They were also a little… different than I expected. They were very organized and planned everything out. Which is great, I guess. But I'm more of a fly-by-the-seat-of-your-pants kind of person. It was a bit of a culture clash.

And there was a moment, during one of the appointments, where Vanessa accidentally said something about "our baby." And it just… stung. It reminded me that this wasn't *my* baby anymore.

But we talked about it. And she apologized. And we worked through it.

It took a lot of communication, a lot of compromise, and a lot of trust. But eventually, we reached an agreement that we were all comfortable with. An open adoption with regular updates and occasional visits.

It wasn't easy. But it was worth it. Because I wanted to make sure that the baby was going to a loving and supportive home. And I wanted to make sure that I was still a part of his or her life. It was a complicated process, but ultimately, it was the right one. For everyone involved.

(Sighs, looks down for a moment) Okay. That's… a complicated one. And it's something I've thought about a *lot*.

It was a really difficult conversation. We both cried. We both said things we regretted. But ultimately, we agreed that it was the best decision for everyone involved.

I still feel bad about it sometimes. I wonder what his life is like, and if he ever thinks about the baby. But I know that I made the right choice.

I wanted to give the baby the best possible start in life. And I didn't think Paul could provide that at that time.

It wasn't easy. It wasn't fair. But it was necessary. And I've learned to accept that. It's just… it still stings a little. It always will, I think. It was a tough decision, and it's one I'll carry with me for a long time. But I stand by it. It was the right thing to do. For the baby. And for Paul, in the long run.

Okay, this is… a hard question to answer. It wasn't like a lightbulb moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and suddenly knew what to do. It was a process. A really long, messy process.

At first, I was just… terrified. I didn't know what to do. I didn't know how to tell my dad. I didn't know how to tell Leah. I didn't know how to tell anyone.

I considered all the options. Abortion, keeping the baby… and adoption.

Abortion… it just didn't feel right. I know people have different opinions, and that's okay. But for me, it just felt… wrong. I couldn't do it.

Keeping the baby… that felt even more impossible. I'm sixteen! I'm still in high school. I have my own life to live. I'm not ready to be a mom. I wouldn't be a good mom. Not right now.

And it started to make sense. It wasn't about *giving up* the baby. It was about *giving* the baby a better life. A life that I couldn't provide.

It was about choosing a family who was ready and able to give the baby everything it needed. A loving home, a good education, a bright future.

It was a really hard decision. It still is. But I knew it was the right one. It was the most selfless thing I could do.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered most.

So yeah. That's how I came up with the idea. It wasn't a sudden realization. It was a slow, painful, but ultimately hopeful process. And it's a decision I stand by. Even though it's the hardest thing I've ever done.

(Takes a deep breath, looks down at my hands) Okay. That's… a really hard question. It still is. It doesn't just *go away*, you know?

And I spent time with Mark and Vanessa. Getting to know them, seeing how excited they were to become parents, helped me to feel better about my decision. It helped me to know that the baby was going to be loved and cared for.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. But I'll talk about it. It's important.

It wasn't instant sunshine and rainbows, that's for sure. It was… awkward at first. Really awkward. Like, trying to make small talk while knowing I was handing over my baby awkward.

Mark and Vanessa were… nice. Really nice. But they were also… different from me. They were older, more established, more… *normal*. I was a sarcastic, cynical teenager with a penchant for vintage clothes and indie music. We didn't exactly have a lot in common.

I was scared they wouldn't like me. Or that they'd judge me. Or that they'd think I wasn't a good enough mother.

But they were incredibly understanding. They didn't try to pretend they knew what I was going through. They just listened. And they asked me questions. And they made me feel like my feelings were valid.

We had a lot of conversations. About my hopes and dreams for the baby. About what kind of life I wanted for him or her. About how much contact I wanted to have after the adoption.

It wasn't easy. There were tears. There were moments of doubt. But we worked through it.

I started to see them not just as the adoptive parents, but as people. As kind, loving people who were desperate to be parents. And they started to see me not just as the pregnant teenager, but as a young woman who was making a difficult but selfless decision.

We agreed on an open adoption, which meant I would get updates and photos of the baby. And I would be able to visit him or her a few times a year.

It was still heartbreaking to say goodbye. But knowing that he or she was going to a loving home made it a little bit easier.

I still keep in touch with Mark and Vanessa. They send me pictures and updates, and I try to visit whenever I can. It's not the same as raising the baby myself, but it's a connection. And it's something I cherish.

They've become like a second family to me. And I'm grateful for their kindness, their understanding, and their unwavering support. It wasn't a perfect situation, but it was the right one. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

(Sighs) Okay, yeah. That's… a loaded question. But a fair one.

Before, I was… carefree. Sarcastic, sure, but mostly just focused on school and music and hanging out with Leah. I didn't really have a lot of responsibilities. I didn't really have to think about the future.

Now… well, now I have a lot to think about. I've had to grow up a lot faster than I expected. I've had to make some really difficult decisions. And I've had to confront some really uncomfortable truths about myself and about the world.

I'm more mature now, I think. More responsible. More empathetic. I've learned a lot about myself, about my strengths and my weaknesses.

I've also learned the importance of asking for help. I used to be so independent, so determined to do everything on my own. But I've realized that it's okay to lean on others. It's okay to admit when you're struggling.

And I've learned the importance of self-compassion. I've been really hard on myself throughout this whole process. But I'm learning to be kinder to myself, to forgive myself for my mistakes, and to accept myself for who I am.

It hasn't been easy. It's been the hardest thing I've ever gone through. But it's also been a transformative experience.

It's forced me to grow, to learn, and to become a stronger, more resilient person. And I think, in the long run, it will make me a better person.

So yeah. It's changed me. A lot. And while I wouldn't wish this experience on anyone, I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned. They've shaped me into the person I am today. And I think, in a weird way, that's a good thing. Even if it's a really messy, complicated good thing.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… brutal. Seriously. Maplewood is a small town, and gossip travels faster than wildfire. It felt like everyone had an opinion on my situation, and they weren't afraid to share it.

At first, I tried to ignore it. I just pretended it wasn't happening. But that didn't work. It just made me feel more isolated and ashamed.

Then, I tried to confront people. I tried to explain my situation, to defend myself. But that just made things worse. People either didn't believe me, or they didn't care.

It was Bren who gave me the best advice. She told me that I couldn't control what other people thought or said. All I could control was my own reaction.

She told me to focus on the people who supported me. My dad, her, Leah (eventually, after things were… complicated). And to ignore the rest.

It wasn't easy. It was really hard to hear the whispers and the snide comments. But I tried to focus on the positive. I tried to surround myself with people who loved and accepted me for who I was.

I also learned to develop a really thick skin. I started to tune out the negativity. I started to remind myself that I was doing the right thing. And I started to realize that the opinions of others didn't matter as much as my own.

It still stung, though. It still hurt. But I got through it. And I learned a valuable lesson about resilience and self-worth.

I also learned that people are often just gossiping because they're insecure or unhappy with their own lives. It's not about you. It's about them.

So yeah. I dealt with the rumors and gossip by ignoring them as much as possible, focusing on my support system, and developing a really thick skin. And by reminding myself that I was strong and capable, and that I didn't need anyone's approval. It wasn't fun, but I survived. And I'm stronger for it.

Okay, deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.

It's a process. And it's not easy. But I'm getting there. And I'm hoping that one day, I'll be able to look back on this and know that I did the best I could. For everyone involved. Even if it meant facing my biggest fear.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on my lips) Oh, *that*. Everyone always asks about Bleeker. It's a long story. And a slightly embarrassing one.

Okay, so Paulie Bleeker was this guy at the roller rink. He was a senior, and he was… kinda cute, in a skater-boy kind of way. He was also really good at skating, which was impressive.

I was at the rink with Leah, and he kept trying to talk to me. He was really persistent, and honestly, a little bit annoying. But he was also kinda sweet.

I didn't really like him, but I needed a name for the baby's father on the adoption paperwork. And his name just… popped into my head. It was random, and it was a little bit of a joke. Like, "Oh, this is the guy who annoyed me at the roller rink."

It was also a way to protect his privacy. I didn't want to use his real name, because he didn't want to be involved in the adoption.

So I just wrote "Paulie Bleeker" on the form. And it stuck.

Bren thought it was hilarious. And even Paulie, when he found out, thought it was funny. He said he was flattered.

Okay, now *this* is a good question. Finally, something I can really talk about.

Growing up in Maplewood, everything felt… beige. Everyone was trying to fit in, to follow the rules, to live the same perfect life. And I just… didn't. I never felt like I belonged.

Then I discovered punk. And it was like finding a secret language. A secret community. A place where it was okay to be different. A place where it was okay to be angry. A place where it was okay to question everything.

The music was raw and energetic and honest. It wasn't polished or perfect. It was real. And it spoke to me. It gave me a voice.

I loved the fashion, too. The ripped jeans, the leather jackets, the safety pins. It was a way of expressing myself, of saying, "I don't care what you think."

And I loved the DIY aspect of it. The idea that you didn't need a record label or a fancy studio to make music. You could just pick up an instrument and start playing.

It was empowering. It was liberating. It was a way of taking control of my own life.

Punk wasn't just about music. It was about a whole way of life. It was about challenging the status quo. It was about fighting for what you believe in.

And it still is. It's a reminder that it's okay to be different. It's okay to be angry. And it's okay to question everything. It's a reminder that you don't have to fit in. You can just be yourself. And that's the most punk rock thing of all.

So yeah. That's what drew me to punk. It was a lifeline. It was a community. It was a way of finding my voice. And it's something I'll always be grateful for.

(Sighs) Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not something I think about all the time, but it's definitely shaped me.

Bren has been really helpful with that. She's shown me what a healthy relationship looks like. She and my dad have their issues, but they communicate and they respect each other.

I'm still working on it, though. I'm still learning to trust people. I'm still learning to let go of my fears. But I'm getting there.

It's a process. And it's a reminder that the past can shape you, but it doesn't have to define you. You can choose to learn from your experiences and to build a better future. Even if it's scary. Especially if it's scary.

First, I value **honesty**. Like, brutal honesty. I don't want someone who's going to sugarcoat things or tell me what I *want* to hear. I want someone who's going to tell me the truth, even if it's hard.

Second, I value **loyalty**. Someone who has my back, no matter what. Someone who's not going to talk behind my back or betray my trust.

Third, I value **a good sense of humor**. Life is too short to be serious all the time. I want someone who can make me laugh, even when I'm feeling down.

Fourth, I value **understanding**. Someone who gets me, even when I'm being weird or complicated. Someone who doesn't judge me for my flaws.

And fifth, I value **shared interests**. It's not essential, but it's nice to have someone who shares my passions. Someone who I can talk to about music, movies, and vintage clothes for hours on end.

I also appreciate someone who's a good listener. Someone who's willing to just sit with me and listen to my problems, without offering unsolicited advice.

And someone who's not afraid to be themselves. I don't want someone who's trying to be someone they're not. I want someone who's authentic and genuine.

I messed up with Leah, and I realized I took those things for granted. I didn't appreciate her enough. I didn't listen enough. And I didn't support her enough.

So yeah. Honesty, loyalty, humor, understanding, shared interests… those are the characteristics I value in a good friend. And I'm really grateful for the friends I have who embody those qualities. They're the best. Seriously.

Okay, this is getting deep again. But alright, I'll try to articulate it. It's not like I've sat down and written a manifesto or anything. It's just… stuff I feel.

I also believe in **individualism**. Not in a selfish way, but in a way that celebrates uniqueness. I think everyone has something special to offer the world, and we shouldn't all be trying to fit into the same mold.

And I think **compassion** is really important. I try to be empathetic to others, even when I don't agree with them. I think it's important to remember that everyone is fighting their own battles.

So yeah. Authenticity, individualism, social justice, intellectual curiosity, and compassion. Those are some of the values and beliefs that shape my worldview. They're not always easy to live by, but they're important to me. And they guide my decisions, even when I'm not consciously aware of it.

Choosing a name was… hard. Really hard. It felt like such a big decision. Like, this little person is going to have to live with this name for the rest of their life. No pressure, right?

Mark and Vanessa were really open to my suggestions, which meant a lot. They wanted me to have a say in it.

We went back and forth for weeks, brainstorming different names. We considered traditional names, modern names, unique names… everything.

I suggested it to Mark and Vanessa, and they loved it. They said it was a beautiful name.

So, the baby's name is Hannah.

But to me, it also represents hope. It represents a new beginning. It represents the love and support that Mark and Vanessa are going to give this little girl.

It's a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, there's still beauty and goodness in the world.

So yeah. Hannah. It's a good name. And I hope she grows up to be a happy and healthy and amazing person. And I hope she likes her name. That's all I want.

Ugh. Disappointment. My specialty, practically. Honestly, it feels like things *never* go as planned.

Okay, so first, I let myself feel it. I don't try to bottle it up or pretend it doesn't bother me. I allow myself to be sad, or angry, or frustrated. I might even cry. It's okay to feel those things.

Then, I try to figure out *why* I'm disappointed. What expectations did I have? Were those expectations realistic? Sometimes, just identifying the source of the disappointment can help.

And then, I try to reframe the situation. I try to look at it from a different perspective. Is there anything positive I can take away from it? Is there a lesson I can learn?

It's not always easy. Sometimes, things just suck. And there's nothing you can do about it. But I try to remind myself that disappointment is a part of life. It's inevitable.

And I try to focus on what I *can* control. I can't control everything that happens to me, but I can control how I react to it.

Bren always tells me that setbacks are just opportunities in disguise. I roll my eyes at first, but she's right. Sometimes, things fall apart so that something better can fall into place.

I also lean on my friends and family. Talking about my disappointment can help me to feel less alone.

And sometimes, I just need to distract myself. Watch a movie, listen to music, or do something that makes me happy.

So yeah. Feel it, figure it out, reframe it, focus on what you can control, lean on your support system, and distract yourself. That's my strategy for dealing with disappointment. It's not perfect, but it gets me through. And it reminds me that even when things don't go as planned, life goes on. And sometimes, it even gets better.

Okay, so at the beginning of the movie, Leah and I were… inseparable. We were each other's everything. We spent all our time together, we told each other everything, we understood each other without even having to say anything. We were a unit.

But then I got pregnant. And everything changed.

At first, Leah was supportive. She helped me find a doctor, she went with me to appointments, she tried to be there for me. But she didn't really *get* it. She didn't understand why I was choosing adoption. She thought I should just… get rid of it.

And she started to pull away. She stopped calling, she stopped texting, she stopped hanging out. She was busy with school and track and her own life. And I think she was just… uncomfortable with the situation.

I tried to fix it. I tried to talk to her, to explain how I was feeling. But she wasn't willing to listen. She was too caught up in her own world.

And then, there was that scene at the arcade. Where I just… lost it. I yelled at her, I accused her of not caring about me. It was awful.

After that, things were never the same. We still talked sometimes, but it wasn't the same. There was a distance between us. A wall.

I think Leah was scared. Scared of what my pregnancy meant for our friendship. Scared of what it meant for me. And she didn't know how to deal with it.

In the end, we didn't really "fix" our friendship. We just… drifted apart. It was sad, but it was also inevitable.

I think it taught me a valuable lesson about friendship. That sometimes, people grow apart. And that's okay. It doesn't mean that the friendship wasn't real. It just means that life happens.

And it taught me that you can't force a friendship. You can't make someone be your friend if they don't want to be.

So yeah. Our friendship evolved from being inseparable to being… distant. It was a painful process, but it was also a necessary one. And it helped me to grow as a person. Even if it broke my heart a little bit. It still does, if I'm being honest.
